pr_title: Fix the partitions deletion from the subquery expressions.

timeline.message:
Make WhereClause#hasQuery return false if query is a value symbol.

This change fixes the regression introduced by
https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9707 in the `WhereClause`.
The `WhereClause#hasQuery` before the removal of the `QuerySpec`
retuned the false if the normalized query was a symbol of the value type.
This change restores the previous behaviour.

timeline.bodyText:
Looking at some of the usages I think this could also lead to bugs if the query is a literal false.
Maybe we should combine this with canMatch ?
timeline.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: hm do you mean combine it with the method body logic query != null && !query.symbolType().isValueSymbol() or at the hasQuery call sides? Combining it in the method body would probably be semantically incorrect Another possible solution would be just using canMatch in the DeletePlanner instead of !hasQuery https://github.com/crate/crate/blob/master/server/src/main/java/io/crate/planner/statement/DeletePlanner.java#L136 and leave the hasQuery without further modifications.
replies.author: kovrus

replies.bodyText:
Another possible solution would be just using canMatch in the DeletePlanner instead of !hasQuery

I like that solution 👍
replies.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText:
Although I think it would also change semantics? If there still is a query, then it's not guranteed that it matches the entire query?
I think we'd have to be explicit and check that either there is no query, or it matches everything
replies.author: mfussenegger

timeline.message:
Fix the deletion of partiitions from the subquery expressions.

This change fixes the regression introduced by
https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9707 in the `WhereClause`.
The `WhereClause#hasQuery` before the removal of the `QuerySpec`
retuned the false if the normalized query was a symbol of the value type
represented by Literal.TRUE. This change address this issue in the
DeletePlanner by adding an additional `canMatch` check when deciding
which delete plan to execute.

Fix the partitions deletion from the subquery expressions.

This change fixes the regression introduced by
https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9707 in the `WhereClause`.
The `WhereClause#hasQuery` before the removal of the `QuerySpec`
retuned the false if the normalized query was a symbol of the value type
represented by Literal.TRUE. That resulted in the wrong plan that would
leave empty orphaned partitions after the delition.

This change address this issue in the DeletePlanner by adding an additional
`canMatch` check when deciding which delete plan to execute.

timeline.author: mfussenegger

replies.bodyText: Yep, true. WIll check the quality against the Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE 👍 tnx
replies.author: kovrus

timeline.message:
Fix the partitions deletion from the subquery expressions.

This change fixes the regression introduced by
https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9707 in the `WhereClause`.
The `WhereClause#hasQuery` before the removal of the `QuerySpec`
retuned the false if the normalized query was a symbol of the value type
represented by Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE. That resulted in the wrong plan that
would leave empty orphaned partitions after the delition.

This change address this issue in the DeletePlanner by adding an additional
where clause = Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE check to decide which delete plan to execute.

Fix the partitions deletion from the subquery expressions.

would leave empty orphaned partitions after the delition.

This change address this issue in the DeletePlanner by adding an additional
where clause = Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE check to decide which delete plan to execute.

Fix the partitions deletion from the subquery expressions.

This change fixes the regression introduced by
https://github.com/crate/crate/pull/9707 in the `WhereClause`.
The `WhereClause#hasQuery` before the removal of the `QuerySpec`
retuned the false if the normalized query was a symbol of the value type
represented by Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE. That resulted in the wrong plan that
would leave empty orphaned partitions after the delition.

This change address this issue in the DeletePlanner by adding an additional
where clause = Literal.BOOLEAN_TRUE check to decide which delete plan to execute.
